Does anybody remember this diner before the "Empire Diner" of the seventies and eighties?  When I used to serve early Mass as an altar boy at Guardian Angel on Saturdays, I'd stop in for an English Muffin and a cup of tea...which cost, maybe a quarter. There were cops, longshoremen, Con-Ed crews and neighborhood regulars having breakfast...None of that glitterati trash! I was born and raised in a pre-gentrigfied Chelsea...when the area was a bit more gritty and far less pretentious.

When I was a young lawyer I represented (the lucky) Wes Moore's mother in a malpractice suit arising from the death of Wes's dad in a suburban Washington emergency room. The hospital knew they had erred. They basically accepted our entire settlement demand after the first depositions.

I shall always remember Wes's mother. She was brave, stoic, and had only one motivation: the welfare of her children. I am sure she is proud of her son, and, in a small way, so am I.

A previous comment on this editorial began this way:

"News flash Mr. Kristoff

At least 98% of the US do not give a hoot about Dafur. They don't care. They aren't interested. If they have read your endless diatribes on the subject, they are sick of it."

It goes on to discuss the importance of focusing on domestic needs and charity. While domestic needs are real, and important, the parallels to rhetoric from the late 1930s is chilling. If you replace "Darfur" with "Jews" or "Austria" or "Poland" the comments could have just as easily been published in 1938-39. There were many serious domestic needs then as well, and many voices calling for the US to focus on itself.

I think in both cases the implication is there is an either/or choice, which is a classic fallacy. Focusing purely on domestic or global needs are not the only two choices and do not have to be mutually exclusive. Implying the people of Darfur can just "revolt" and take care of themselves is as ill-informed as implying all the homeless here have to do is "get a job." The ills of the world are rarely that simple.

The US has made good and bad choices in international intervention, and those choices have changed the world in both positive and negative ways. But I would argue that coming along side the suffering men. women, and children of Sudan is as much a moral imperative as coming along side the suffering men, women and children in our own communities and in fact, the US IS serving its own citizens but joining with other countries to help those who cannot help themselves.

I believe we could all learn something about how to face cancer, and how to live life, from my not-yet-four-year-old son Austin, who has battled kidney cancer (bilateral Wilms tumor, a rare childhood cancer affecting both kidneys) twice since he was ten months old.

When something hurts, he cries then and there, but he never dwells on what's already happened to him and he never worries about what's about to happen to him. And he never ever feels sorry for himself.

He has laughed and hopped and jumped and cartwheeled through hundreds of days in the hospital, through six abdominal surgeries, through radiation and chemotherapy (twice). I have spent many an hour maneuvering an unwieldy IV pole over door jambs and around corners as he's raced around the halls on a tricycle at the very moment that chemo is being pumped through his veins.

He has giggled contagiously as he lets me attach play-doh horns to his perfectly clean bald head in an attempt to turn him into a triceratops. He has sat patiently through eight-hour blood transfusions, content to watch the construction happening outside his window. He has honed his toddler flirtation skills on his favorite nurses, calling them endlessly from the button on his bed.

I would never wish cancer on anyone and I would certainly never wish cancer upon anyone's child. But there is a special joy in watching a bald and supposedly sick child live every minute to the fullest. You cannot truly know the meaning of "joie de vivre" until you have seen this particular child hop, skip and jump down the hospital hallways.

This has been, in a strange and unexpected way, our greatest gift.

I think that part of the reason that many successful strategies aren't followed is that political correctness gets in the way. Clarence Page's editorial today speaks to half of that problem. Another side has to do with empowerment of women that started by necessity in World War II (divorce rates peaked when the war ended partly because women found they didn't need a man) it settled down after a couple of years, but peaked in the 70s and 80s as women gained greater prominence in the work place and easy contraception meant they didn't need to be tied down to children. All the while the traditional family has eroded to the point we are today. Even though intensive early childhood education and mentoring are great tools, they will not put the genie back in the bottle. We need to find ways to bring the traditional family back into the projects, removing the penalties for having a working parent in the family, maybe even creating welfare incentives for having a traditional family. There is much to do, but the current ways aren't working, perhaps looking back to a time when things worked better is a path worth exploring.

It's unlikely that any programs will significantly reduce the poverty in which many black Americans live. The reason this is true is that racial differences in intelligence are at least partially genetic, and thus unchangeable.

This is not about poverty alone, but about the whole set of pathological behaviors identified by Sen. Moynihan four decades ago.

I live in a school district that includes some of the nation's wealthiest families, along with a number of families who live in low-income housing. One of my neighbors has spent years teaching in the elementary school that serves the poorer kids. The kids in that school whose parents take an active interest in their education tend to make it. Those in dysfunctional families, with absentee or addicted parents tend to fail. My neighbor recently disciplined one of the failing kids who was disrupting her class. The next day his mother complained to the principal, because the teacher was not "respecting" her kid. Unfortunately, the mother has the roles reversed. The student should be respecting the teacher.

Organizations like City Year and Dream Academy can make a difference, but simply increasing the amount spent per student is not necessarily the answer, This has long been proven by parochial schools, that often spend far less per student than the public schools.
Along the theme of absent fathers, I would suggest one way of addressing the issue through the lens of Robert Bly in "Iron John: A book about men"....

I stayed at the Marina Mandarin, great hotel, fantastic views and location, couldn't have been happier, though, if I wanted to pay more, maybe one of the older places would have been nice. Singapore is a fantastic place to visit, but I do recommend you find a hotel near the river or the marina. there's a lot of hotels along orchard road, which is fine if you like shopping malls, but the riverbanks also have malls, and it is much, much more pleasant along the river, and the marina. you can read more about my experience in 48 hours in Singapore at travel.spinfirst.com - wonderful trip!

Imagine a reporter entered your just dead mother's apartment, snooped about with the custodian who just bashed in her locked door, maybe he lifted a few 'juicy' items, maybe he photographed things that seemed 'odd' to the 'reporter,' then wrote up his impressions of your dead mom's last days, and then got it published by the Times because either your mom was news worthy, or the socalled 'snapshot' was just so clever/ cute/ compelling/ compassionate--whatever.  Yes, my sister and I would be offended, we'd be furious, and we would hire the nastiest lawyer money we could find, and we would go for the public settlement, not some coverup.  New York Times you are the greatest paper in the world.  I've been reading you since 1979, but you are losing your way.  Admit your errors, turnaround and do the real work you meant to do.

I am unable to defend any current media coverage of any person or personal subject. A public deprived of authority in their own lives is hungry for knowledge of other's, hence all the alienating 'reality' or star shows. But let me speak about the artist who is not always the glitzy vapid character the public supposedly wants:  Writing, practicing, creating requires lots of silence and lots of time undisturbed. Touring is exhausting. Performing is intense, and intensely social before, during and after the work is done. How much actual space does a person need and want? Pleasure is a comfortable room and bed , a desk, a piano,   friends, family, work. The rest of the society's expectations are corrupt and ignorant. It sounds like  this wonderful life and wonderful artist has all and everything he needs and desires.

Thank you for your eagle eye and thoughtful discussions.  As a retired journalism professor who taught courses in ethics for two decades, as well as having decades of newsroom experience, I know well that ethics is a collision of values, not right-or-wrong.  I have been surprised, in recent years, at the general absence of poltical bias in the Times news columns.  I'm sure having a public editor helps keep reporters and editors more aware of possible ethical breaches.

If recollection serves, there was only one matter on which I flat-out disagreed with you. That probably means I didn't read everything else with my critical faculties sufficiently engaged. What I think your columns most often made evident, however, is that agreement or disagreement is not what's most important. What perhaps mattered most in your work was getting the issues out in the open, sorted and defined, able to be recognized and considered by writers and editors as the same types of issues arise again and again, as they surely will.

I won't bother to mention the issue on which I disagreed. As Mr. Keller pointed out, sometimes one is simply left to disagree. But I do want to say that I respected enormously your work on the things you mentioned in this last column: questionable uses of anonymous sources, opinion creeping into news analysis (moreover, it sometimes seems that there is little straightforward "reporting" in The Times these days), and preservation of quality on the Internet. Thanks for all the journalistic and newspaper business enlightenment. All best wishes for your future endeavors.

"But they get much, much more right than wrong."

This column would be a lot more convincing if you didn't boast of being so chummy with the folks you were hired to scrutinize. I don't know if you're looking for another gig, but I hear the Minerals Management Services have some openings.
